content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting ; I mistakenly thought yesterday that today was going to be a planning meeting, but I was wrong. Today is backlog bonanza, compiler-team#484
@Jack Huey has prepared the initial doc, thank you so much for that Jack. It is here: https://hackmd.io/h_tyzNEKS_Kc2OY_rSm28g
There are 16 issues listed there
I suspect we won't be able to get through all 16 in an hour
It's a bit sparse on details (just a list of issues and links), but should be enough to drive discussion
Only 16?
oh no
So many
yeah I should have realized that was wrong
goodness, is there more than 200 ?
no
Another point: if issues didn't have an appropriate team label, it will be included. So it's not unlikely some of these won't actually be T-compiler
okay so lets think for just a moment about how best to spend this time
in the lang team, we just have a list that's a queue
and we don't try to get through all of them
but rather, we accept that its going to take several rounds of meetings
So my first instinct is to do just taht
Agreed
walk through each item, figure out status and what next steps are, if any
@Wesley Wiser do you have any suggestions for improving on that?
Yes. Should we adopt the same status labels as lang?
No, that sounds good. I would only add that we should also try to consider if some of the older issues should simply be closed (for a variety of reasons).

so the lang team status labels are as follows:

  • S-tracking-ready-to-stabilize: Needs a stabilization PR (good to go :train:)
  • S-tracking-needs-to-bake: Needs time to bake (set a date? other criteria?)
  • S-tracking-impl-incomplete: Not code complete or blocking bugs
  • S-tracking-unimplemented: Implementation not begun
  • S-tracking-design-concerns: Blocking design concerns
    • This might be "doesn't quite seem to deliver value we hoped for" or "something doesn't feel right"
  • S-tracking-perma-unstable
    • Internal implementation detail of rustc, stdlib
  • S-tracking-needs-investigation
do these seem like these work for us?
Looks pretty good
I'm willing to go with it. If nothing else, they already exist as labels
so okay, lets go ahead with the first item on the list

"Implement where clauses" rust#17657

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/17657
this description was last updated in 2017
and no real comments on thread since 2015
there are seven listed tasks, five of which are checked off
The last checkbox is still unimplemented
the two unchecked tasks have issues that are indeed not closed
Seems S-tracking-impl-incomplete?
that's what I was thinking
Yeah
are there any feature gates that should be listed on this description here?
The last item is itself a C-tracking-issue :laughing:
#20041 is?
Yeah
oh yeah, I see the label now
One question though: It might be the case that these just don't get implemented
so for #20041, it appears to be S-tracking-unimplemented, right?
I know Niko has had some concerns about arbitrary where clause equality constraints
okay, so maybe #20041 is S-tracking-design-concerns ?
maybe both? I don't know if these labels are meant to be exclusive, especially in that case
I think lang should be tagged in this for "if these should still be implemented"
okay
left comment and updated labels on #20041
next

"Parse and accept type equality constraints in where clauses" rust#20041

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/20041
oh
just handled that
next

"Tracking issue for Consistent no-prelude attribute (RFC 501)" rust#20561

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/20561
no tasks lists in description, which hasn't been touched since it was first written in 2015 (and was just a link to rfc#501 )
last comment was in 2016
with pointer to bit-rotted PR #32025
Seems like it's implemented but not stabilized?

@Steve Klabnik said in 2016 that:

Triage: so. This RFC happened pre-1.0, yet never landed. And it seems no_implicit_prelude does work on stable today. So, this would have to not be a re-naming, but a deprecation + new name?
and then we had PR #80427 more recently

where @Vadim Petrochenkov pointed out:

The PR is from 2016 and the RFC is from 2014, the whole idea should probably be revised before proceeding.

In recent years #[no_implicit_prelude] was mostly used in compiler tests and by people wanting to stress the compiler, it was also a source of problems during macro modularization and other name resolution changes. I'd personally be more interested in removing #[no_implicit_prelude] than in adding one more similar attribute.

and likewise @oli added :

The PR is from 2016 and the RFC is from 2014, the whole idea should probably be revised before proceeding.
In recent years #[no_implicit_prelude] was mostly used in compiler tests and by people wanting to stress the compiler, it was also a source of problems during macro modularization and other name resolution changes.
I'd personally be more interested in removing #[no_implicit_prelude] than in adding one more similar attribute.

I have no real knowledge of this area, but I agree that just the existance of an RFC does not motivate the change, and I'm not sure the original motivation still applies (considering that there was no activity on the tracking issue for years).

cc @Kimundi @Nemo157 how do you feel about abolishing this scheme entirely and coming up with something new that does not conflict with macro imports?
So
Sounds like this should just be scrapped?
S-tracking-design-concerns ?
S-tracking-design-concerns ?
at the very least we need to revisit the original motivation
design concerns and, yeah, I would tend to agree with closing (with fcp or not).
Or should this just be closed? AIUI it's already implemented and available on stable?
the situation feels prety confusing to me
#![no_implicit_prelude] doesn't throw any stability error on playground for me
It's even documented in the reference https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/names/preludes.html#the-no_implicit_prelude-attribute
Well, I think this is for no_prelude
And deprecating no_implicit_prelude
how about ths
tag with S-tracking-design-concerns, and fcp close
Next isn't a T-compiler issue
I didn't filter out T-core
Removing from the doc
(As we go, let's make sure the relevant issues are tagged T-compiler if they aren't)
next

"Tracking issue for FastISel" rust#26600

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/26600
another one from 2015
definitely in @WG-llvm balliwick, yes?
Should this kind of issue actually be tagged C-tracking-issue?

Not really a tracking issue, and some of the recent commentary suggests that this is something LLVM is moving away from anyway -- but I would be inclined to ping wg-llvm and ask if they want to just close it.

GlobalISel is intended to be a replacement for SelectionDAG and FastISel, to solve three major problems:

(https://www.llvm.org/docs/GlobalISel/index.html)
(I realize it says "tracking issue for ..." :smile: but the tag description mentions RFCs and unstable features which this is neither)
I would be totally happy untagging, but then I would also want to just close it :)
Agreed
I guess the presence of subtasks was why it got C-tracking-issue, though I suspect if none of those subtasks has an actual separate issue assigned, then the label isn't really helpful
is @nagisa or @Nikita Popov here?
If either one of them were to :thumbs_up: closing this, then I'd say just do it
maybe I'll just do that and cc them in the comment
For #27579, this is rough. Definitely needs a T-lang, and probably a WG-traits tag.

"Projections, lifetimes, and WF tracking issue (RFC 1214)" rust#27579

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/27579
what about the S-tracking-* label, @Jack Huey ? or do you think T-lang/WG-traits should be the ones to figure that out?
I think maybe S-tracking-needs-investigation is best as a tracking issue tag; ideally we better delineate the work here in wg-traits
I don't really know if this is best as a tracking issue
But it is design work that needs to be tracked
there is no S-tracking-needs-investigation
do you mean S-tracking-needs-summary ?
Hmm, it was in the list you wrote above
huh
you're right
needs-summary is fine
I transcribed my list from a hackmd, but github is source of truth
Or design-concerns. Whatever label is most appropriate for "this is work that needs to be done, but not sure the best way to track it"
I cannot even tell that from what's here, so needs-summary seems good to me
I went ahead with that
next

"Tracking issue for Allow a re-export for main (RFC 1260)" rust#28937

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/28937
main got removed, right?
Or something related

What's the current state of this? Are people using it successfully? Is it a potential candidate for stabilization?

It's fully implemented, and the tests pass. There're no known technical limitations, but I'm not aware whether there're people using it today in nightly builds. I think it's a potential candidate for stablization.

From 20 days ago
okay so comment thread was useufl here
S-tracking-ready-to-stabilize right?
Yeah, and maybe I-lang-nominated to kickoff an FCP?
oh @Josh Triplett already tagged it with S-tracking-needs-summary
(That summary was provided, though, at least in very brief).
it also doesn't have a T- label
I guess an FCP is a bit early, but maybe we can get someone to write a stabilization report.
it certainly sounds like this is in T-lang's court
If we're not sure if anyone is using it, it feels too early to stabilize to me.
so time-to-bake ?
Maybe just needs a T-lang label then
not sure if we should relabel?
Guess it doesn't hurt
if there's not anyone using it, does time-to-bake help?
T-lang, I guess. I'd probably nominate for lang discussion on either moving ahead or removing it, personally -- if no one wants it, maybe it should just be dropped.
(versus, I don't know, evalgelism+advocacy?)
Just question would be needs-to-bake or ready-to-stabilize
I think +T-lang +I-lang-nominated

pnkfelix said:

if there's not anyone using it, does time-to-bake help?

I would say what we're waiting for is experience reports. Evangelism + advocacy could potentially help on that front.
left a comment and added T-lang and I-lang-nominated
next

"Create a benchmark suite for uncovering runtime regressions" rust#31265

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/31265
Hmm
seems like this needs some initiative
@anp sounded pretty engaged with it as of ... November 2020
Is this really a tracking issue
I think this is actually one of the aspirational goals we identified for 2022.
this is another case where a list of tasks led to this being labelled as tracking, I think
May be worth closing in favor of https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/issues/69.

[Quoting…]
maybe, though that's seen far less activity

Yeah, for sure -- maybe moving it over to rustc-perf. I feel like it's (at least in my mind) a good idea to have these two share a lot of the underlying infra, as they have much the same needs in terms of display, analysis, etc
I'm in favor of closing
(In any case, IMO not a tracking issue).
Or moving
lets shift it over to rustc-perf then
I don't think we should close but it doesn't feel like a tracking issue to me. Moving to rustc-perf would also be ok.
I'm only closing to try to force others to migrate to point at the rustc-perf issue instead. Maybe foolish.
but we are overloaded with issues on rust-lang/rust and so I'm entirely in favor of trying to migrate when it makes sense.

(i.e. in this case, I don't think there's useful metadata in terms of intra-repo linkage that would motivate keeping this issue here. There are other issues where linking within the repo is super-valuable and thus motivates keeping an issue within rust-lang/rust)
#37403 is labeled, T-dev-tools, so maybe we don't need to discuss
huh
lets look at it nonetheless

"Tracking issue for #[link(kind)] connecting libraries on Windows" rust#37403

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37403
Why is this tagged T-dev-tools?
Seems like a lang/compiler feature.
Yeah, I think it was moved over from T-tools without too much thought.
I think back then there was also more ambiguity over whether dev-tools or compiler owned the compiler CLI interface (at least my vague recollection is such)
is it also T-lang , or just T-compiler ?
Is this needs-to-bake, ready-to-stabilize, or needs-summary?
I think its needs-summary
I think so too

pnkfelix said:

is it also T-lang , or just T-compiler ?

Feels like T-compiler to me.
Not sure how tests look for this, or if this is something worth stabilizing
I was under the impression that all of that is stable already
I guess we need a summary ;)

This is the commeent I left:

From quickly skimming the comments here, I can tell there are people invested in this feature, but I cannot tell what its current status is (how much has been stabilized, how much was insta-stabilized, how much is still unstable), nor how much remains to be done, if anything.
petrochenkov has been quite a bit of work around #[link] recently and he assigned this to himself a few weeks ago.
right, the fact that @Vadim Petrochenkov self-assigned implies to me that there is still useful work to be done here
anyway needs-summary seems fine to me
next

"debuginfo: How to (ideally) represent reference and pointer types in DWARF" rust#37504

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/37504
hey sounds like a job for WG-debugging. (Or "who ya gonna call? WG-debugging!")
I don't think this is a tracking issue
There's some useful discussion there -- but it's not a tracking issue, yes
yep, okay, lets just remove the label then
So -C-tracking-issue +WG-debugging?
It's already tagged A-debuginfo so we'll be able to find it a later.
WG-debugging doesn't exist (yet!)
at least not as a label
but yeah, @Wesley Wiser has the right idea
Is it actually useful to have both A-debuginfo and WG-debugging? Seems like those sets would mostly overlap :)
there's lot of places where that happens
Another T-dev-tools label
For the next

Wesley Wiser said:

Is it actually useful to have both A-debuginfo and WG-debugging? Seems like those sets would mostly overlap :)

(I think this is a broader pattern (anti-pattern?) that we'll need to answer for at some point
i.e. I think there are coherent reasons for having distinct labels in such cases, but I cannot formulate them at the moment
I guess WG-debugging could mean "the working group is actively tracking this" or something.
but pre-emptively tagging issues with WG- doesn't make sense then ...
also there might end up being things that are not debuginfo but are still WG-debugging
I think the current state is fine. Let's move on? :smile:
yeah

"Tracking issue to stabilize --print target-spec-json" rust#38338

Link: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/38338

This question seems pertinant:

Is there motivation from your end to have this on stable, rather than nightly-only?
Seems like it's semi-stable, with a push to fully destabilize it?
#71009

Could we perhaps stabilize the output as "subject to change" in a sense that new values can be added and existing values removed only guaranteeing that the meaning of an existing value does not change? I think most consumers of this output will be perfectly capable of dealing with this.

I don't know how I feel about this philosophy

am I out of touch in thinking "a user who's willing to deal with output that is subject to change" is probably also willing to either 1. use a nightly , or 2. use the env var that makes stable think its nightly
I think we should not be encouraging use of the env that must not be named :silence:
it seems like a pretty strong stability guarantee
obviously I must be wrong, or else people wouldn't be asking for this
I think for JSON output it feels weird to say 'may change drastically'; at the very least I would want some opt-in
If the only "stable" guarantee is that its going to effectively render teh current (unstable) target spec
is that a reasonable "stable" guarantee to put forward? I'm not sure how meaningful it is, though I can see value in it
(i.e. its way easier in some cases to call an option like this than to figure out where the definition is for a target spec...)
People like having --emit mir,llvm-ir etc on stable compilers even though the output isn't stable.
This specific argument feels similar to me.
that's an important precedent. I like that
I think those are much harder to parse, though
There's also a related question: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/71009
oh lets finish this, the hour is up

The original post says this:

This issue is meant to track the stabilization of the rustc flag --print target-spec-json which will output the currently selected target as a valid target spec that can be loaded with --target for only the same version of the compiler that generated it.

Which seems reasonable
S-tracking-ready-for-stabilization ?
-T-dev-tools +T-compiler too
How much should the outcome of #71009 affect this?
they seem tightly coupled to me
We could add a header to the --print target-spec-json output that makes it invalid json and warns people to not depend on the output similar to --emit mir.
IE, if we decide to destabilize target spec JSON input, should we still stabilize the print option?
okay I no longer think we can come to a conclusion in support of S-tracking-ready-for-stabilization
so I'm going to tag with S-tracking-needs-summary instead
and try to point out the issues that were raised here
or maybe S-tracking-design-concerns ?
hmm

Wesley Wiser said:

IE, if we decide to destabilize target spec JSON input, should we still stabilize the print option?

Rename it to --print target-spec first and allow the output to be human readable rather than json if we don't accept json target specs anymore?
yes I think the latter S-tracking-design-concerns reflects current feelings

thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending! Have a great day everyone!

(and get proposals in for next week's planning meeting. :laughing: )
This was productive
But also, I have no clue how we get through 155 of these
We should maybe consider adding 2-3 to each weekly meeting
Gotta spend some time outside of meetings to work on that list...

I wonder if next time we could also have everyone grab 2-3 issues at the beginning of the meeting, take 5 minutes, read through them, come up with a short summary and post a recommendation? And then we spend the meeting going through that set?
It may go faster that way instead of us all reading the issues each time.
I think often we can just let a single person make decisions
Probably some combination of these ideas is the best path
And maybe just summarize what they did
If people are on board, I can get 2 of these onto the weekly meeting
(C-tracking-issue, -S-tracking*)

Jack Huey said:

If people are on board, I can get 2 of these onto the weekly meeting

@apiraino can you update the template to support this ?

At least from the issues we went through today, there's probably a lot more that are either: not actually waiting on our team or are not actually tracking issues. Doing something more async would help us not waste too much time on those issues.

Jack Huey said:

But also, I have no clue how we get through 155 of these

hmm, took an hour to get through 10...

pnkfelix said:

Jack Huey said:

If people are on board, I can get 2 of these onto the weekly meeting

apiraino can you update the template to support this ?

I can make a triagebot PR. I need to update the query code so it filters out S-tracking*
I think encouraging async work is good, but I wouldn't rely on it alone
so far, my experience has been that these meetings dedicated to backlog can act as really good "forcing functions"
Yeah, I wonder if it's helpful to write a summary comment without necessarily adding a S-tracking?
Like, for me personally, about half of these I don't have the broader context to really know the right tracking status. But it's easy enough to summarize existing discussion.
I think that would be really useful!
